Changes In Rules Adopted—Milton Erlanger Elected To Executive Board
Of Eastern Collegiate Lacrosse Association.

Its Purpose To Make Closer Relations
Between Different Fraternities.
Composed Of Eighteen Charter
Members—In No Opposition
To O. D. K.

Since the meeting of the Eastern
Collegiate Lacrosse League in New
York on January 15, 1921,• at
Which the schedules of games between members Of the league were
finally arranged Manager Keyes
is able to announce that the Varsity will play as follows:
April 16—Alumni.
April 23—University of Pennsylvania.
April 30—Syracuse.
May 7—Stevens (away).
May 14—Navy.
.May 21—Swarthmore.
May 28—Lehigh (away).
June 4-:-Mount Washington.
June 11—Toronto. .

June . 18 — Crescent
(away).
It is thought probable that
Princeton can be gotten to play
at Homewood on April 16, in
which event the Alumni game will
be played a week earlier than on
the present schedule. The championship game with Lehigh, the
last of the league games, will be
on the latter's field at South Bethlehem. The lateness of commencement, which does not come until
June 21 this year, makes it possible to include Toronto on its
spring trip southward, and a game
with the well-known Crescents in
New York.
Johns Hopkins sent two delegates to the league conference,
"Father Bill" Schmeisser and Captain Bartow Griffiss, the former
being made a member of the committee to arrange schedules and
change the rules of the games. Of
interest to Johns Hopkins was the
election of Milton Erlanger of Baltimore, a former captain, as member of the executive board of the
association.

played upon and the width of the
field. Fouls will be classified into

off the field for a few minutes to

The most recent addition to the
already long list of organizations
for the improvement of undergraduate conditions at Hopkins
has been made with the formation
of the Sigma Chi Beta Honorary
Fraternity.
The purpose of the chapter, coinposed of 18 charter members, all
undergraduate fraternity men, is
to bring the different fraternities
represented at the University into
closer touch with each other and
to materially reduce, if not entirely wipe out, the prevailing spirit
of distrust and lack of co-operation which have so long been the
bane of interfraternity relations
at Hopkins.
The organization of the fraternity was commenced during the
first part of December and after
much work on the part of its members has just recently been completed. Its members are and will
always be upper classmen, it being
generally agreed that there is less
likelihood on any mistake in the
choice of men after their first year
in college, which is usually sufficient to bring out both good and
• bad points.
At present seven of the nine fraternities represented on the interfraternity board, as well'as three
others which have no chapters at
Hopkins, have members in Sigma
Chi Beta and .it is expected that
all will be represented directly
after the election of new members,
due to take place shortly, and to
add some dozen men to the chapter roll. According to a provision
of the constitution, no more than
four members of one fraternity
may at the same time be active
members of the honorary society,
thus removing all possibility of
one chapter gaining control.
Contrary to views held* by some
on the campus, Sigma Chi Beta is
to be in no way construed as to be
running in opposition to Omicron
Delta Kappa. Whereas 0. D. K.
strives to promote the welfare of
the college and to bring about its
recognition from the. outside by
rewarding leadership in activities
which make Hopkins favorably
known to outsiders, ,Sigma• Chi
Beta is working for the internal
welfare of the University through
its endeavors to promote friendship among the different factions
which have so much to do with the
regulation of student' affairs.

FEBRUARY 4

The Swimming Team outclassed Swarthmore last Friday night
at the B. A. C. pool and ran away with the meet to the tune of 48 to
14. The interest of the night was furnished by• the splendid work
of our team, which broke three records. Out of the seven events on the
program Hopkins'scored six' firsts and six seconds, Baxter of Swarthmore coming out ahead in the fancy dive and his teammate, McAllister, placing in the plunge. Coady finished the 220-yard swim in the
5, knocking 11/5 seconds off the old Hopkins record
/
fast time of 2.482
made last year. In the plunge Hambleton bettered the old mark by
2 feet, while Reins bettered his old
five feet six inches by plunging 591/
2 of a second.
/5 seconds for the back stroke by 1/
record of 271.
0 D K TO AWARD CUP
Will Honor Student Who Has Done
Most For Hopkins During College
Life—Convention To Be Held
.At Lexington, Va.

At the last meeting ot Omicron
Delta Kappa last Thursday night
the circle _decided to give a silver
cup as an award to the 6tudent
who has done most for Hopkins
during his college'course. The conditions of the award have not been
dfinitely dcided, but the object is
to recognize and reward tl..e most
conspicuous service to the University. A conimittee is looking into
the best method of selecting the
recipient of this honor and the
choice of judges, as well as the
basis of selection, will be decided
at the next meeting. The circle
is endeavoring to promote several
methods of fostering activities,
and it is hoped that this prize will
incite interest and keen competition.
The national convention of O. D.
K. is to be held on February 5 at
Lexington Va., where there is a
circle in Washington and Lee University. Norman Keyes has been
elected to represent Hopkins and
Dr. French, who is president of
the society, will also attend. The
next meeting has been postponed
on account of examinations 'to Friday, February 11, at 12.30 o'clock.
The list of charter members of
the new fraternity follows: T. M.
Berry, R. F. Bowers, H.P. Brauner, Fred Bresee, E. H. Cashell, J.
A.. DeForce, J. J. Dubbledee, G.
C. Engel, Bartow Griffiss, R. C.
Hall, N. J. Howard, N. E. Miller,
Jr., E. M. Pickford, M. F. Rogers,
J. C. Thompson, W. J. Totterdale,
0. S. Wilkinson and C. B. Wright.

Hopkins started well by winning the relay handily when Rowland finished half a lap ahead of
his man. The fancy diving came
next and Baxter, of Swarthmore,
earned the decision over Call.
Rowland won the 40-yard dash
with room to spare, but Johnston
and Martin, of Swarthmore,
fought it out for second, with the
former winning by inches. Early
in the 220 it was seen that Coady
was hitting up a fast pace and he
drew away from his competitors.
He weakened toward the last, however, and Gould drew up, with a
pretty finish between them resulting. In the plunge Hambleton
failed by six inches to make the
length of the pool, but he was far
ahead of his nearest rival. At the
request of Swarthmore the breast
stroke was eliminated and the
back stroke swum in its place.
Reins and "Bob" Hall finished this
in what seemed almost a dead
heat, but which the judges decided
was not, Reins being given the decision. Swarthmore deserves great
credit for carrying out this event,
as neither of her entrants had ap:
parently swum the back stroke before. The 100-yard swim finished
the meet with Rowland and Buhrer, of Hopkins, nosing out Baker,
of Swarthmore.
The support accorded the team
was disgusting. The number of
students present could almost be
counted on the fingers of both
hands and they received the announcements of the. breaking of
the records with philosophical
calm. It is hard for a team to do
its best if the student-body is not
behind it, so it is hoped that every'body will turn out for the cOming
meets. On-February 4 the University of Pittsburgh is coming here
with a crack team. They swam
the Y. M. C. A. here several years

It has been definitely decided by
the athletic authorities at Princeton University that that institution will be represented next
spring by both varsity and freshman teams in lacrosse. The value
of this sport as a conditioner
for athletes engaging in other
branches, particularly football, is
being realized more each year.
Princeton expects to join the intercollegiate league in the season
of 1922.

LACK OF CO-EDUCATION
AT HOPKINS FELT
Dramatic Club Forced To Change Title
Of Play On Account Of The Lack
Of The "One" Woman. President Trew Explains
Difficulties.

(

All because of one woman the
Dramatic Club has found it necessary to change the play for March
11 from "Lady Windermere's Fan"
to "Arms and the Man," by George
Bernard Shaw. It is probably not
SO much because of this• one
woman as the lack of one since it
was found impossible to find anywhere in the University an actor
•to take the leading feminine role
of Mrs. Erlynne. There were several aspirants but just as in the
case of casting Eurelia in "Captain Jinks of the Horse Marine"
there were none who had the
natural charms to put themselves
naturally in the part and carry it
as Oscar Wilde has made. it.
The new choice, "Arms and the
Man," will have seven speaking
parts and several non-speaking
which will be filled by those who
have shown up best in the tryouts
and rehearsals which have been
going on since the early part of
the. year. The plav is in three acts
staged in Bulgaria during the
Serbo-Bulgarian War of 1885 and
depicts a romance involving officers of both sides.
Bartus Trew, president of the
club, in a letter to the NEWS-LETTER has made the following report
on the change:
As the University has been following with so much interest the
activities of the Dramatic Club,
not only in a general way but by
its allotment in the new nonathletic budget has shown a material
interest, it is only fair that a
statement should be made to the

has been called off and that with

with a possibility of playing it in

University for what must seem an
apparent delay in the choice of a
play as the major production for
this year.
What may seem indecision is in
reality experimentation; which is
hi its very nature essential to play.
producing. it is impossible to
judge of the ability of an actor
until lie has been tried out. It is
to be remembered that last year
.:t matic Club lost six experienced men by graduation and
when activities were again resumed this fall not only were the
officers of the club but also Miss
Walter ignorant of the available
material. Although nearly 50 men
tried out, it was found impossible
to cast the first play decided upon,
"Captain Jinks," which was unfortunate both because it offered
a large cast and because it embodied a little of the idea of musical comedy, an end toward which
the club is striving. The second
choice proved equally unsuccessful and our final selection has been
made to fit our material, always
remembering that "Arms and the
Man" embodies all the literary
values and effects of the club's
former production.
I may say still further the very
heavy expense involved in the pro-,
duction of many plays that could
otherwise have been done precluded them, as the club is financially unable to stand a production
,f this type.
I am certain that the studentbody will agree with the Dramatic
Club in their final - action and
therefore leave the advisability of
it to you all who witness "Arms
and the Man" at the Lyric on
March 11.
BAirrus TRIM, President.

"Eddie" Hulburt Elected Honorary
President Of '23.

Dr. Edward Hulburt was
elected honorary class president
at a meeting of the Sophomore
class held last Thursday at 12.20
o'clock. . Dr. Hulburt, who has
always been very popular with
everyone connected with the University, is an ex-captain of the
Hopkins lacrosse team and saw
service overseas during the recent
The class considers it a
war.
(Treat honor to have such a man
for its honorary president.
It was decided at the meeting to
hold the Sophomore dance on February 25. One hundred couples
only will be admitted, and if there
is any surplus of tickets after all
the Sophomores desirous of attending are accommodated, they
will be open to purchase by members of the other classes. Louis
Fisher's Orchestra has been engaged and it is emphasized that
the dance is to be formal. The
class decided to rigidly enforce
the freshman regulations next
week, which is the last week of
their existence and plans were
made for that purpose.

FRESHMEN QUINT LOSES
TO QUAKERS
Friends Take Return Game—Freshman
Fight Hard In Second Half, But
Are Unable To Overcome
Opponents Lead.

- In their third start this season
the Freshmen five was defeated
for the first time by Friends
School on the latter's floor by the
score of 13 to 11. After having
defeated the quintet from the
Park Avenue School several weeks
ago by a narrow margin at the
Armory and having gained a de
eisive victory over the Severn
School last week, the Freshmen
were confident of their third consecutive win in as many starts
when they lined up for action
Wednesday evening, but the Quakers set a mark in the first half
which the first-year men did not
pass nor even equal at any stage
of the game.
From the time the first whistle
blew every Quaker was in the fray
with all his might and main and
they fooght like Trojans, allowing
only one point to be scored against
them in the first half while they
totaled 11, due mainly to the brilliant work of Berndt, who was
easily the individual star of the
game, scoring 11 of the 15 points
which his team made in the entire game.
In the second half the Freshmen
came back strengthened; they
fought hard and it seemed as
though they would win, gradually
overcoming the lead which Friends
had taken during the earlier
stages of the game,but the Quakers
proved equal to the occasion and
when time was called the score
stood 15 to 11 in their favor. In
this period the "Freshies" scored
10 points to their opponents' 4,
which in itself is indicative of the
fact that the first-year men fought
and fought hard. Captain Strouse
did not show up well in shooting
fouls, caging only two out of eight
trials and making only one field
goal. Hutzler scored six points
and played the best game for the
Freshman five.

NEWS-LETTER WILL NOT APPEAR
NEXT WEEK.

There will be no publication of
the NEWS-LETTER for the week of
This omission is
February 1.
made necessary by the fact that
the advertising contracts cover 30,
while the school year calls for
some 33 issues. Three issues must
therefore be omitted. Since there
will be no news of any considerable value on this date, it is thought
that this issue may most readily
be spared. One issue has already
been made up during the Christmas holidays, and the third will
be made up at Easter.

.The NEWS-LETTER heartily indorses the plan of the Omicron
Delta Kappa Society in giving a
cup to the student who has done
the most for Hopkins during his
college course. It believes that
such an award would arouse interest and stimulate competition
among the student-body.
The proposal as it now stands,
however, practically limits the
award to Seniors only. Would not
the prize accomplish more if given
yearly to the student who has done
the most for Hopkins during that
year, with, probably, certain restrictions, so that the same man
cannot win the cup twice in sue:.
cession?
The committee will face many
difficulties both in the selection of
a-guitable basis for the award and
a suitable body of judges. The
society cannot very well undertake to judge the contest itself, as
more than likely the prize will go
to one of its own members.
A committee of the faculty.
would not be likely to be sufficiently well informed, nor should
the matter be left to popular vote.
In fact the selection of the judges
will require considerable tact and
foresight, although it is probable
that a committee composed of faculty and student representatives
will form the best solution of the
difficulty.

The Navy 'Athletic Association
and the Penn State Athletic Association which petitioned for membership were turned down. Efforts to have lacrosse in future
Olympic programs were begun by
preparing proposals to be presented to the International Olympic Committee at its next meeting.
The Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association is made up of two divisions, the northern division including Harvard, Yale, Cornell,
Hobart and Syracuse, and the
southern division, Stevens Tech,
Pennsylvania, Lehigh, Swarthmore and Johns Hopkins.
The Varsity squad is holding
four practices a week, regardless
of the coldness of the weather.
There will be some letup during
examinations, but the work will
be resumed immediately thereafter: As much new equipment
as is possible will be obtained to
fully equip the team for the coming season.

THE "HONOR SYSTEM."

The term "Honor System" is in
itself a contradiction, for the
Honor System is no system at all.
The word "system" carries with
it an idea of elaborateness, of complications and of details, while the
Honor System means one thing
only—that we are expected to be
fair, honest and decent without
the stimulus of a hawk-eyed monitor's tireless vigilance.
It seems little enough to ask
that each man do what he himself
knows to be right. The examination or quiz paper is expected to
be a test of the knowledge of the
student whose name it bears, and
not of the man in the next seat.
There are many harsh words
which might be applied to the man
who turns in the work of another
as his own; the least that we can
say is that he does not belong at
Hopkins.
The question is one for each one
of us to decide—to be just tO ourselves and to others. No one need
tell us how to do this; we all
know. If by chance one among us
does not, it is the duty of all of us
to see that his connection with the
University ceases.

The Student Council of 1921 has
proved itself worthy of the trust
imposed in it by the student-body.
It has taken an active part in the
college life and has not shirked the
most unpleasant duties.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 25, 1921

PROF. R. W. WOOD GIVES nitely until the liquefaction temperature is reached. It is only re" INTERESTING LECTURE
Liquefaction

of

Gases Subject of

Talk—Illustrates Some

of the

Qualities of Liquid Air.

-

Last Thursday, during the general assembly hour, Prof. Robert
W. Wood gave a most interesting
lecture on the liquefaction of gases
before an audience of students
which taxed the capacity of the
M. E. lecture-room. The lecture
was arranged by Professor Bliss
mainly for the benefit of his
physics classes, but the interest
of the subject and the reputation
of the speaker drew many in addition. Professor Wood is well
known throughout the country for
the wonderful work he did for the
Government on balloon gases during the war and his remarkable
discovery of the "invisible eye,"
Which sees with ease colors in the
spectroscope which heretofore no
one has known much about.
Professor Wood opened his talk
With a short discussion of the
theory of the liquefaction of gases,
telling of the early discoveries of
the fact that they could be liquefied. Michael Faraday was the
first to realize that some oily
drops, in a tube of chlorine which
he had, were in reality liquid
chlorine. Professor Wood went
on to tell of the first attempts to
liquefy other gases and the failures which resulted. It was not
until the apparatus now commonly used was thought of that the
gases most difficult to liquefy were
conquered. This apparatus depends on the fact that a gas cools
as it expands. The gas is first put
under great pressure and then
Passed through a series of copper
coils which allow it to expand.
These coils are,in turn,surrounded
by an outer jacket, so that when
the first of the gas comes out of
the stopcock at the bottom it is
cooled probably 30 degrees below
room temperature and passes up
between the coils and the jacket,
bringing the former to its temperature. Thus when the second portion of gas comes out it is reduced
to 60 degrees below room temperature. This is continued indefi-

cently that helium, which requires
the lowest temperature, has been
liquefied by first subcooling it
with liquid air.
Professor Wood next brought
out some liquid air and displayed •
some of its qualities. It was quite
a surprise to many that the air
can be kept a number of days in
receptacles like thermos bottles.
As the air was poured from vessel
to vessel it boiled and hissed, giving it quite a fearsome appearance.
Professor Wood dropped alcohol
and mercury into it and they froze
instantly. Flowers when dipped
into it appeared the same, but
crumbled to nothing at a touch.
Professor Wood closed the lecture by taking some of the air
into his mouth for a minute. This
feat elicited much applause.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 25, 1921

8

PLANS. FOR ARMORY MEET
WELL UNDER WAY

GOULD TO REPRESENT
HOPKINS

Over Forty Colleges To Enter—Good
Seating Facilities—Hopkins To Be
Represented By Large Squad.

P. C. Williams Chosen Alternate—
Trials for Tocqueville Medal to
Be Held February 11.

Every advance indication points
to the largest and most successful
indoor meet ever conducted by
Johns Hopkins at the Fifth
Entrance
Regiment Armory.
blanks, which have recently been
mailed, are being filled out
by over 40 colleges including
most of the leaders of the track
sport in the country.
Harvard, Cornell,.Pennsylvania,
Yale, Princeton, Penn State,
Georgia Tech and others are
grooming their best athletes for
the test in Baltimore. In addition
to the college stars many of the
best club and high school stars
will be on hand for the competition.
The seating arrangements will
provide unusual facilities for a
clear view of the proceedings.
Homewood's circus seats will be
set up all around the 220-yard
track and one section at each end
will be reserved for the contestants
so that they will not obstruct the
view of the spectators. These seats
and those in the first row of the
north and south balconies will set
the enthusiast back $1.50, war tax
included. The second and third
rows in these balconies will tax
their occupants only $1, and the
mob can stand for a paltry 75
cents.
Among the big feature races
will be the renewal of the Varsity
1000-yard special, the South Atlantic collegiate mile relay championships, the Middle States mile
relay championships, the Maryland Interscholastic mile relay
championship and the four-mile
international schoolboy relay between City College and Toronto.
The Hopkins tearn is fast rounding into unusually good shape for
this season of the year. The unusual number and high quality of
the candidates make sure a good
showing at the games at which
they will act as hosts. It is highly
probable that there will be few
races in which two or three of
the leading contenders are not
Hopkins men. The weakness in
field events is being remedied and
with the appearance of a few more
weight-throwers and jumpers this
branch of the sport should be as
strong as the running side.
Honor System Is Live Topic.

The honor system continues to
be the subject of discussion in
American colleges. It has recently
been adopted in the military department of Colorado Agricultural
College by the students of Ohio
S tat e University, GustavusAdolphus College, Minnesota, and
Valparaiso University, Indiana.
Other student bodies having the
same under consideration are
Bethany College, West Virginia;
Coe College, Iowa; University of
Michigan and Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College.

Tryouts were held Friday to select an undergraudate of the University, who will be sent to the
University of North Carolina in
March to represent Johns Hopkins
in the Annual Southern Oratorical
Contest.
Out of twelve men who participated in the trials, C. I. T. Gould,
Jr., was chosen as representative
and P. C. Williams as alternate.
Their subjects were "Business Reconstruction" and "The Restriction of Immigration," respectively.
The Southern Oratorical League
is formed of seven universities,
namely, Vanderbilt, Tennessee,
Kentucky, Alabama, North Carolina, Virginia and Johns Hopkins.
A contest is held each year at one
of the competing colleges; where
speeches not exceeding 20 'minutes in length are made dealing with subjects of current, political or social interest.
Cash prizes are awarded for
first, second and third place.. Last
year the prizes were $25, $15 and
$10.
The trials for speakers to compete for the .Tocqueville Medal,
awarded by Baron Pierre de Couberten, will be held February 11
and the finals will be given during
assembly several weeks later. The
subject for the year 1921 will be
"France as a Colonial Power," and
contestants will choose a subtopic
upon which they will speak for a
period of five minutes.

Undergraduate Orchestra To Play At
Student Assemblies.

The Undergraduate Orchestra,
under the capable direction of
"Mike" Bowers, is rapidly acquiring a finished touch. The orchestra was inaugurated at the beginning of the collegiate year, when
it was evident that there .waFi sufficient talent among the students to
justify the formation of such an
organization and regular renearsals have been held every Thursday night since.
The student orchestra has given
several public performances which
has reflected favorably upon the
orchestra and the University. A
rehearsal was recently given at
the Baltimore City College, and
was greatly appreciated by the
audience. The quality of the music
rendered by the orchestra at the
Freshmen-Sophomore debate was
most creditable and added much
to the pleasure of the evening. The
orchestra is now directing it activity in anticipation of its performance at the Dramatic Club
play. The orchestra also is planning to play at a number of the
general assemblies later in the
year.

body at Hopkins has made mani-

Hopkins Twirlers To Meet Dartmouth.

The baseball schedule for the
spring season is shaping up well
and promises to be one of the best
that Hopkins has had for several
years. By far the major number
of games will be played at Homewood this year and, as stated in
the NEWS-LETTER several weeks
ago, there will be plenty of interval between each match so that
pitchers will not be played out as
they were • last season. For this
year, even more than last, promises to see the University short of
twirlers.
The latest addition to the
schedule is a game with Dartmouth on April 2. Negotiations
are being carried on with Brown
University for a game here on
March 28—Easter Monday.

The most recent addition to the
already long list of organizations
for the improvement of undergraduate conditions at Hopkins
has been made with the formation
of the Sigma Chi Beta Honorary
Fraternity.
The purpose of the chapter, coinposed of 18 charter members, all
undergraduate fraternity men, is
to bring the different fraternities
represented at the University into
closer touch with each other and
to materially reduce, if not entirely wipe out, the prevailing spirit
of distrust and lack of co-operation which have so long been the
bane of interfraternity relations
at Hopkins.
The organization of the fraternity was commenced during the
first part of December and after
much work on the part of its members has just recently been completed. Its members are and will
always be upper classmen, it being
generally agreed that there is less
likelihood on any mistake in the
choice of men after their first year
in college, which is usually sufficient to bring out both good and
• bad points.
At present seven of the nine fraternities represented on the interfraternity board, as well'as three
others which have no chapters at
Hopkins, have members in Sigma
Chi Beta and .it is expected that
all will be represented directly
after the election of new members,
due to take place shortly, and to
add some dozen men to the chapter roll. According to a provision
of the constitution, no more than
four members of one fraternity
may at the same time be active
members of the honorary society,
thus removing all possibility of
one chapter gaining control.
Contrary to views held* by some
on the campus, Sigma Chi Beta is
to be in no way construed as to be
running in opposition to Omicron
Delta Kappa. Whereas 0. D. K.
strives to promote the welfare of
the college and to bring about its
recognition from the. outside by
rewarding leadership in activities
which make Hopkins favorably
known to outsiders, ,Sigma• Chi
Beta is working for the internal
welfare of the University through
its endeavors to promote friendship among the different factions
which have so much to do with the
regulation of student' affairs.

Life—Convention To Be Held

At the last meeting ot Omicron
Delta Kappa last Thursday night
the circle _decided to give a silver
cup as an award to the 6tudent
who has done most for Hopkins
during his college'course. The conditions of the award have not been
dfinitely dcided, but the object is
to recognize and reward tl..e most
conspicuous service to the University. A conimittee is looking into
the best method of selecting the
recipient of this honor and the
choice of judges, as well as the
basis of selection, will be decided
at the next meeting. The circle
is endeavoring to promote several
methods of fostering activities,
and it is hoped that this prize will
incite interest and keen competition.
The national convention of O. D.
K. is to be held on February 5 at
Lexington Va., where there is a
circle in Washington and Lee University. Norman Keyes has been
elected to represent Hopkins and
Dr. French, who is president of
the society, will also attend. The
next meeting has been postponed
on account of examinations 'to Friday, February 11, at 12.30 o'clock.

heat, but which the judges decided

parently swum the back stroke before. The 100-yard swim finished
the meet with Rowland and Buhrer, of Hopkins, nosing out Baker,
of Swarthmore.

calm. It is hard for a team to do

behind it, so it is hoped that every'body will turn out for the cOming

Dramatic Club Forced To Change Title
Of Play On Account Of The Lack
Of The "One" Woman. President Trew Explains
Difficulties.

(

All because of one woman the
Dramatic Club has found it necessary to change the play for March
11 from "Lady Windermere's Fan"
to "Arms and the Man," by George
Bernard Shaw. It is probably not
SO much because of this• one
woman as the lack of one since it
was found impossible to find anywhere in the University an actor
•to take the leading feminine role
of Mrs. Erlynne. There were several aspirants but just as in the
case of casting Eurelia in "Captain Jinks of the Horse Marine"
there were none who had the
natural charms to put themselves
naturally in the part and carry it
as Oscar Wilde has made. it.
The new choice, "Arms and the
Man," will have seven speaking
parts and several non-speaking
which will be filled by those who
have shown up best in the tryouts
and rehearsals which have been
going on since the early part of
the. year. The plav is in three acts
staged in Bulgaria during the
Serbo-Bulgarian War of 1885 and
depicts a romance involving officers of both sides.
Bartus Trew, president of the
club, in a letter to the NEWS-LETTER has made the following report
on the change:
As the University has been following with so much interest the
activities of the Dramatic Club,
not only in a general way but by
its allotment in the new nonathletic budget has shown a material
interest, it is only fair that a
statement should be made to the

producing. it is impossible to

remembering that "Arms and the

duction of many plays that could

therefore leave the advisability of

and the Man" at the Lyric on

"Eddie" Hulburt Elected Honorary
President Of '23.

Dr. Edward Hulburt was
elected honorary class president
at a meeting of the Sophomore
class held last Thursday at 12.20
o'clock. . Dr. Hulburt, who has
always been very popular with
everyone connected with the University, is an ex-captain of the
Hopkins lacrosse team and saw
service overseas during the recent
The class considers it a
war.
(Treat honor to have such a man
for its honorary president.
It was decided at the meeting to
hold the Sophomore dance on February 25. One hundred couples
only will be admitted, and if there
is any surplus of tickets after all
the Sophomores desirous of attending are accommodated, they
will be open to purchase by members of the other classes. Louis
Fisher's Orchestra has been engaged and it is emphasized that
the dance is to be formal. The
class decided to rigidly enforce
the freshman regulations next
week, which is the last week of
their existence and plans were
made for that purpose.

FRESHMEN QUINT LOSES
TO QUAKERS
Friends Take Return Game—Freshman
Fight Hard In Second Half, But
Are Unable To Overcome
Opponents Lead.

- In their third start this season
the Freshmen five was defeated
for the first time by Friends
School on the latter's floor by the
score of 13 to 11. After having
defeated the quintet from the
Park Avenue School several weeks
ago by a narrow margin at the
Armory and having gained a de
eisive victory over the Severn
School last week, the Freshmen
were confident of their third consecutive win in as many starts
when they lined up for action
Wednesday evening, but the Quakers set a mark in the first half
which the first-year men did not
pass nor even equal at any stage
of the game.
From the time the first whistle
blew every Quaker was in the fray
with all his might and main and
they fooght like Trojans, allowing
only one point to be scored against
them in the first half while they
totaled 11, due mainly to the brilliant work of Berndt, who was
easily the individual star of the
game, scoring 11 of the 15 points
which his team made in the entire game.
In the second half the Freshmen
came back strengthened; they
fought hard and it seemed as
though they would win, gradually
overcoming the lead which Friends
had taken during the earlier
stages of the game,but the Quakers
proved equal to the occasion and
when time was called the score
stood 15 to 11 in their favor. In
this period the "Freshies" scored
10 points to their opponents' 4,
which in itself is indicative of the
fact that the first-year men fought
and fought hard. Captain Strouse
did not show up well in shooting
fouls, caging only two out of eight
trials and making only one field
goal. Hutzler scored six points
and played the best game for the
Freshman five.

.The NEWS-LETTER heartily indorses the plan of the Omicron
Delta Kappa Society in giving a
cup to the student who has done
the most for Hopkins during his
college course. It believes that
such an award would arouse interest and stimulate competition
among the student-body.
The proposal as it now stands,
however, practically limits the
award to Seniors only. Would not
the prize accomplish more if given
yearly to the student who has done
the most for Hopkins during that
year, with, probably, certain restrictions, so that the same man
cannot win the cup twice in sue:.
cession?
The committee will face many
difficulties both in the selection of
a-guitable basis for the award and
a suitable body of judges. The
society cannot very well undertake to judge the contest itself, as
more than likely the prize will go
to one of its own members.
A committee of the faculty.
would not be likely to be sufficiently well informed, nor should
the matter be left to popular vote.
In fact the selection of the judges
will require considerable tact and
foresight, although it is probable
that a committee composed of faculty and student representatives
will form the best solution of the
difficulty.

preparing proposals to be presented to the International Olympic Committee at its next meeting.

southern division, Stevens Tech,
Pennsylvania, Lehigh, Swarthmore and Johns Hopkins.

be resumed immediately thereafter: As much new equipment
as is possible will be obtained to
fully equip the team for the coming season.

THE "HONOR SYSTEM."

The term "Honor System" is in
itself a contradiction, for the
Honor System is no system at all.
The word "system" carries with
it an idea of elaborateness, of complications and of details, while the
Honor System means one thing
only—that we are expected to be
fair, honest and decent without
the stimulus of a hawk-eyed monitor's tireless vigilance.
It seems little enough to ask
that each man do what he himself
knows to be right. The examination or quiz paper is expected to
be a test of the knowledge of the
student whose name it bears, and
not of the man in the next seat.
There are many harsh words
which might be applied to the man
who turns in the work of another
as his own; the least that we can
say is that he does not belong at
Hopkins.
The question is one for each one
of us to decide—to be just tO ourselves and to others. No one need
tell us how to do this; we all
know. If by chance one among us
does not, it is the duty of all of us
to see that his connection with the
University ceases.

The Student Council of 1921 has
proved itself worthy of the trust
imposed in it by the student-body.
It has taken an active part in the
college life and has not shirked the
most unpleasant duties.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 25, 1921

PROF. R. W. WOOD GIVES nitely until the liquefaction temperature is reached. It is only re" INTERESTING LECTURE
Liquefaction

of

Gases Subject of

Talk—Illustrates Some

of the

Qualities of Liquid Air.

-

Last Thursday, during the general assembly hour, Prof. Robert
W. Wood gave a most interesting
lecture on the liquefaction of gases
before an audience of students
which taxed the capacity of the
M. E. lecture-room. The lecture
was arranged by Professor Bliss
mainly for the benefit of his
physics classes, but the interest
of the subject and the reputation
of the speaker drew many in addition. Professor Wood is well
known throughout the country for
the wonderful work he did for the
Government on balloon gases during the war and his remarkable
discovery of the "invisible eye,"
Which sees with ease colors in the
spectroscope which heretofore no
one has known much about.
Professor Wood opened his talk
With a short discussion of the
theory of the liquefaction of gases,
telling of the early discoveries of
the fact that they could be liquefied. Michael Faraday was the
first to realize that some oily
drops, in a tube of chlorine which
he had, were in reality liquid
chlorine. Professor Wood went
on to tell of the first attempts to
liquefy other gases and the failures which resulted. It was not
until the apparatus now commonly used was thought of that the
gases most difficult to liquefy were
conquered. This apparatus depends on the fact that a gas cools
as it expands. The gas is first put
under great pressure and then
Passed through a series of copper
coils which allow it to expand.
These coils are,in turn,surrounded
by an outer jacket, so that when
the first of the gas comes out of
the stopcock at the bottom it is
cooled probably 30 degrees below
room temperature and passes up
between the coils and the jacket,
bringing the former to its temperature. Thus when the second portion of gas comes out it is reduced
to 60 degrees below room temperature. This is continued indefi-

cently that helium, which requires
the lowest temperature, has been
liquefied by first subcooling it
with liquid air.
Professor Wood next brought
out some liquid air and displayed •
some of its qualities. It was quite
a surprise to many that the air
can be kept a number of days in
receptacles like thermos bottles.
As the air was poured from vessel
to vessel it boiled and hissed, giving it quite a fearsome appearance.
Professor Wood dropped alcohol
and mercury into it and they froze
instantly. Flowers when dipped
into it appeared the same, but
crumbled to nothing at a touch.
Professor Wood closed the lecture by taking some of the air
into his mouth for a minute. This
feat elicited much applause.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 25, 1921

8

PLANS. FOR ARMORY MEET
WELL UNDER WAY

GOULD TO REPRESENT
HOPKINS

Over Forty Colleges To Enter—Good
Seating Facilities—Hopkins To Be
Represented By Large Squad.

P. C. Williams Chosen Alternate—
Trials for Tocqueville Medal to
Be Held February 11.

Every advance indication points
to the largest and most successful
indoor meet ever conducted by
Johns Hopkins at the Fifth
Entrance
Regiment Armory.
blanks, which have recently been
mailed, are being filled out
by over 40 colleges including
most of the leaders of the track
sport in the country.
Harvard, Cornell,.Pennsylvania,
Yale, Princeton, Penn State,
Georgia Tech and others are
grooming their best athletes for
the test in Baltimore. In addition
to the college stars many of the
best club and high school stars
will be on hand for the competition.
The seating arrangements will
provide unusual facilities for a
clear view of the proceedings.
Homewood's circus seats will be
set up all around the 220-yard
track and one section at each end
will be reserved for the contestants
so that they will not obstruct the
view of the spectators. These seats
and those in the first row of the
north and south balconies will set
the enthusiast back $1.50, war tax
included. The second and third
rows in these balconies will tax
their occupants only $1, and the
mob can stand for a paltry 75
cents.
Among the big feature races
will be the renewal of the Varsity
1000-yard special, the South Atlantic collegiate mile relay championships, the Middle States mile
relay championships, the Maryland Interscholastic mile relay
championship and the four-mile
international schoolboy relay between City College and Toronto.
The Hopkins tearn is fast rounding into unusually good shape for
this season of the year. The unusual number and high quality of
the candidates make sure a good
showing at the games at which
they will act as hosts. It is highly
probable that there will be few
races in which two or three of
the leading contenders are not
Hopkins men. The weakness in
field events is being remedied and
with the appearance of a few more
weight-throwers and jumpers this
branch of the sport should be as
strong as the running side.
Honor System Is Live Topic.

The honor system continues to
be the subject of discussion in
American colleges. It has recently
been adopted in the military department of Colorado Agricultural
College by the students of Ohio
S tat e University, GustavusAdolphus College, Minnesota, and
Valparaiso University, Indiana.
Other student bodies having the
same under consideration are
Bethany College, West Virginia;
Coe College, Iowa; University of
Michigan and Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College.

Tryouts were held Friday to select an undergraudate of the University, who will be sent to the
University of North Carolina in
March to represent Johns Hopkins
in the Annual Southern Oratorical
Contest.
Out of twelve men who participated in the trials, C. I. T. Gould,
Jr., was chosen as representative
and P. C. Williams as alternate.
Their subjects were "Business Reconstruction" and "The Restriction of Immigration," respectively.
The Southern Oratorical League
is formed of seven universities,
namely, Vanderbilt, Tennessee,
Kentucky, Alabama, North Carolina, Virginia and Johns Hopkins.
A contest is held each year at one
of the competing colleges; where
speeches not exceeding 20 'minutes in length are made dealing with subjects of current, political or social interest.
Cash prizes are awarded for
first, second and third place.. Last
year the prizes were $25, $15 and
$10.
The trials for speakers to compete for the .Tocqueville Medal,
awarded by Baron Pierre de Couberten, will be held February 11
and the finals will be given during
assembly several weeks later. The
subject for the year 1921 will be
"France as a Colonial Power," and
contestants will choose a subtopic
upon which they will speak for a
period of five minutes.

Undergraduate Orchestra To Play At
Student Assemblies.

The Undergraduate Orchestra,
under the capable direction of
"Mike" Bowers, is rapidly acquiring a finished touch. The orchestra was inaugurated at the beginning of the collegiate year, when
it was evident that there .waFi sufficient talent among the students to
justify the formation of such an
organization and regular renearsals have been held every Thursday night since.
The student orchestra has given
several public performances which
has reflected favorably upon the
orchestra and the University. A
rehearsal was recently given at
the Baltimore City College, and
was greatly appreciated by the
audience. The quality of the music
rendered by the orchestra at the
Freshmen-Sophomore debate was
most creditable and added much

Hopkins Twirlers To Meet Dartmouth.

The baseball schedule for the
spring season is shaping up well
and promises to be one of the best
that Hopkins has had for several
years. By far the major number
of games will be played at Homewood this year and, as stated in
the NEWS-LETTER several weeks
ago, there will be plenty of interval between each match so that
pitchers will not be played out as
they were • last season. For this
year, even more than last, promises to see the University short of
twirlers.
The latest addition to the
schedule is a game with Dartmouth on April 2. Negotiations
are being carried on with Brown
University for a game here on
March 28—Easter Monday.
